text: Direct observations of N2O5 reactivity on ambient aerosol particles
label: BODY

text: Timothy H. Bertram,1,2 Joel A. Thornton,1 Theran P. Riedel,3 Ann M. Middlebrook,4
label: BODY

text: Roya Bahreini,4,5 Timothy S. Bates,6 Patricia K. Quinn,6 and Derek J. Coffman6
label: BODY

text: Received 28 July 2009; accepted 10 September 2009; published 8 October 2009.
label: BODY

text: N2O5 reactivity has been measured directly for the first
label: BODY

text: time on ambient aerosol particles using an entrained aerosol
label: BODY

text: flow reactor coupled to a custom-built chemical ionization
label: BODY

text: mass spectrometer at two urban locations during summer.
label: BODY

text: The observed N2O5 reactivity is a strong function of both
label: BODY

text: relative humidity (RH) and particle chemical composition.
label: BODY

text: We show that particulate organic mass loadings, together
label: BODY

text: with ambient relative humidity, play a leading role in
label: BODY

text: determining the reaction rate of N2O5 with particles. Our
label: BODY

text: observed reactivity values are both more variable and, at
label: BODY

text: times, as much as a factor of ten lower than currently
label: BODY

text: implemented large-scale model parameterizations would
label: BODY

text: predict. Such discrepancies have likely consequences for
label: BODY

text: predictions of NOx availability and ozone production,
label: BODY

text: and the sensitivity of these quantities to aerosol particle
label: BODY

text: loadings. Citation: Bertram, T. H., J. A. Thornton, T. P. Riedel,
label: BODY

text: A. M. Middlebrook, R. Bahreini, T. S. Bates, P. K. Quinn, and
label: BODY

text: D. J. Coffman (2009), Direct observations of N2O5 reactivity on
label: BODY

text: ambient aerosol particles, Geophys. Res. Lett., 36, L19803,
label: BODY

text: Introduction
label: BODY

text: [2] The production of tropospheric ozone (O3), a criteria
label: BODY

text: air pollutant and potent greenhouse gas, is a complex
label: BODY

text: function of nitrogen oxides (NOx = NO + NO2), volatile
label: BODY

text: organic compounds (VOC), sunlight, and trace oxidants
label: BODY

text: such as the hydroxyl radical (OH). O3 production is non-
label: BODY

text: linearly dependent on NOx abundance and thus accurate
label: BODY

text: description of the processes that remove NOx radicals is
label: BODY

text: critical for predicting the down-wind influence of anthro-
label: BODY

text: pogenic emissions on tropospheric O3. Global modeling
label: BODY

text: studies suggest that nocturnal processes involving the
label: BODY

text: reactions of the nitrate radical (NO3) and N2O5 account
label: BODY

text: for 50% of the globally averaged annual net NOx removal
label: BODY

text: [Dentener and Crutzen, 1993]. However, the impact of
label: BODY

text: nocturnal NOx removal processes on the tropospheric O3
label: BODY

text: budget continues to be limited by uncertainty in the reaction
label: BODY

text: rate of N2O5 with aerosol particles.
label: BODY

text: [3] The influence of N2O5 on the removal of atmospheric
label: BODY

text: NOx radicals is determined by the product of the probability
label: BODY

text: that N2O5 will react on a particle given a collision, g(N2O5),
label: BODY

text: and the total gas-particle collision frequency primarily set
label: BODY

text: by the available particle surface area concentration (Sa).
label: BODY

text: Until recently, direct measurements of g(N2O5) have been
label: BODY

text: restricted to the laboratory, where simplified model particle
label: BODY

text: types are probed to ascertain functional dependences. These
label: BODY

text: studies have shown that N2O5 removal by particles and the
label: BODY

text: resulting products are strongly dependent on: i) liquid water
label: BODY

text: content (H2O(l)) [Thornton et al., 2003], ii) particle nitrate
label: BODY

text: (NO3
label: BODY

text: ), which inhibits N2O5 hydrolysis [Wahner et al.,
label: BODY

text: 1998], iii) the presence of additional nucleophiles in water
label: BODY

text: stressed particles [Behnke et al., 1997], iv) organic coatings
label: BODY

text: that have been theorized to either suppress N2O5 accom-
label: BODY

text: modation or decrease water availability at the surface
label: BODY

text: [McNeill et al., 2006; Folkers et al., 2003], and v) particle
label: BODY

text: acidity [Mozurkewich and Calvert, 1988]. These effects
label: BODY

text: lead to measured g(N2O5) that span three orders of magni-
label: BODY

text: tude (1  104 < g < 0.1) depending on the chemical and
label: BODY

text: physical properties of the particles employed. Consistent
label: BODY

text: with this large potential variability, recent analyses of NO3
label: BODY

text: and N2O5 field measurements have inferred that g(N2O5)
label: BODY

text: can range from 1  103 to 0.017 and is likely dependent
label: BODY

text: on particle chemical composition [Brown et al., 2006].
label: BODY

text: [4] In the context of atmospheric particle composition,
label: BODY

text: the importance of the above dependences, either individu-
label: BODY

text: ally or as a whole, remains entirely unclear. Combining our
label: BODY

text: direct measurements of g(N2O5) on ambient particles with
label: BODY

text: co-located observations of particle chemical composition
label: BODY

text: and particle Sa, gas phase precursors, and meteorological
label: BODY

text: parameters, allows such evaluations and the elucidation of
label: BODY

text: factors that most likely control g(N2O5) on ambient particles.
label: BODY

text: Experimental Design
label: BODY

text: [5] The pseudo-first order rate coefficient for N2O5 loss
label: BODY

text: to aerosol particles (khet) was measured directly using an
label: BODY

text: entrained aerosol flow reactor coupled to a chemical ioni-
label: BODY

text: zation mass spectrometer (CIMS) [Kercher et al., 2009].
label: BODY

text: The experimental technique is described in detail elsewhere
label: BODY

text: [Bertram et al., 2009]. Observations of g(N2O5) were made
label: BODY

text: at two urban sampling locations during the summer of 2008.
label: BODY

text: Between July 3rd and 21st, observations were made from a
label: BODY

text: 10 m tower adjacent to the NOAA Earth System Research
label: BODY

text: Laboratory in Boulder, CO. Particle size distributions (65 nm
label: BODY

text: to 1 mm) were measured by an ultra-high sensitivity aerosol
label: BODY

text: spectrometer and particle composition measured by an
label: BODY

text: Aerodyne compact time-of-flight aerosol mass spectrometer
label: BODY

text: [DeCarlo et al., 2006; Drewnick et al., 2005]. Coincident
label: BODY

text: measurements of gas-phase precursors (e.g., O3 and NO)
label: BODY

text: and basic meteorological parameters were also made during
label: BODY

text: the sampling period. Between August 6th and 16th, obser-
label: BODY

text: vations were made from a 5 m sampling mast extending
label: BODY

text: above an instrument sea container located at the NOAA
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: 1 of 5
label: BODY

text: Pacific Marine Environmental Laboratory, 10 km NE of
label: BODY

text: downtown Seattle, WA. Particle size distributions (10 nm to
label: BODY

text: 10 mm) were measured with two differential mobility
label: BODY

text: particle sizing instruments and aerodynamic particle sizer.
label: BODY

text: Sub-micron particle composition was measured by an
label: BODY

text: Aerodyne quadrupole aerosol mass spectrometer [Jayne et
label: BODY

text: [6] We interpret these results using a newly developed
label: BODY

text: parameterization of g(N2O5) [Bertram and Thornton, 2009]
label: BODY

text: that is driven by observations of particle composition and
label: BODY

text: RH, and calculations of H2O(l) as determined by the aerosol
label: BODY

text: inorganics model (AIM Model II) [Carslaw et al., 1995].
label: BODY

text: This approach permits us to directly assess the dependence
label: BODY

text: of the observed g(N2O5) on the factors outlined in section 1.
label: BODY

text: Observed Dependence of g(N2O5) on Particle
label: BODY

text: Chemical Composition
label: BODY

text: [7] In Boulder, the ambient RH was low (30 ± 15%),
label: BODY

text: particle loadings were rather uniform (mean Sa = 108 ± 35,
label: BODY

text: total mass = 5.3 ± 1.5 mg m3), and particles contained high
label: BODY

text: organic mass fractions (mean organic/sulfate mass ratio =
label: BODY

text: 6.1 ± 3.9). The median g(N2O5) observed in Boulder was
label: BODY

text: 0.003 (interquartile range of 0.9–1.2  103). In contrast,
label: BODY

text: in Seattle, the ambient RH was higher (74 ± 13%), particle
label: BODY

text: loadings were enhanced and more variable (mean Sa = 190 ±
label: BODY

text: 115, total mass = 7.2 ± 4.1 mg m3), but particles had similar
label: BODY

text: bulk particle chemical composition as in Boulder (mean
label: BODY

text: organic/sulfate = 7.1 ± 4.8). The median g(N2O5) observed
label: BODY

text: in Seattle was 0.009 (interquartile range of 0.26–2.9 
label: BODY

text: 102), a factor of three larger than measured in Boulder.
label: BODY

text: [8] These differences in the median g(N2O5) are grossly
label: BODY

text: consistent with the difference in RH between the two
label: BODY

text: locations leading to lower H2O(l) in Boulder relative to
label: BODY

text: Seattle. But, RH alone is not sufficient for describing either
label: BODY

text: the observed variability in, or the level of suppression of
label: BODY

text: g(N2O5) relative to that expected on aqueous solution
label: BODY

text: particles. For example, the strongly decreasing trend of
label: BODY

text: g(N2O5) with the increasing mass ratio of particulate
label: BODY

text: organic matter (POM) to sulfate (SO4
label: BODY

text: 2) observed in the
label: BODY

text: Seattle data, and the lack of such a correlation in the
label: BODY

text: Boulder data (Figure 1a), provide insights into the particle
label: BODY

text: characteristics that exert control over g(N2O5). In what
label: BODY

text: follows, we investigate the dependence of g(N2O5) on
label: BODY

text: POM, making the reasonable assumption that the aerosol
label: BODY

text: particles are largely internal mixtures [Murphy et al., 2006]
label: BODY

text: (see auxiliary material).1
label: BODY

text: [9] In the absence of POM, g(N2O5) should be controlled
label: BODY

text: by the RH-dependent liquid water content and the molarity
label: BODY

text: of nucleophiles such as NO3
label: BODY

text:  and chloride (Cl) [Bertram
label: BODY

text: and Thornton, 2009; Griffiths et al., 2009; Wahner et al.,
label: BODY

text: 1998; Behnke et al., 1997]. In both locations studied, when
label: BODY

text: POM/SO4
label: BODY

text: 2 was lowest, the non-refractory particle compo-
label: BODY

text: sition was mainly ammonium sulfate (AS) with trace NO3
label: BODY

text: and Cl (Figure S1), and our observations of g(N2O5) are in
label: BODY

text: good agreement with both laboratory measurements and the
label: BODY

text: parameterization of Bertram and Thornton [2009]. Probing
label: BODY

text: the response of g(N2O5) to an increasing mass fraction of
label: BODY

text: POM, in both Boulder and Seattle, permits us to assess the
label: BODY

text: potential affects of POM on g(N2O5). POM has been
label: BODY

text: suggested to influence g(N2O5) via: i) altering H2O(l),
label: BODY

text: which has been shown to influence g(N2O5) either through
label: BODY

text: a direct H2O(l) limitation [Thornton et al., 2003] or by
label: BODY

text: changing particle [H2O(l)]/[NO3
label: BODY

text: ] [Mentel et al., 1999], and/
label: BODY

text: or ii) the formation of organic coatings on aqueous cores
label: BODY

text: that inhibit the accommodation or reaction of N2O5 [Badger
label: BODY

text: et al., 2006; McNeill et al., 2006; Folkers et al., 2003].
label: BODY

text: [10] The small g(N2O5) values and lack of correlation
label: BODY

text: with POM observed in Boulder indicates that the particles
label: BODY

text: sampled were either solid (independent of POM mass
label: BODY

text: fraction) or that increases in POM did not lead to the
label: BODY

text: associated increase in H2O(l) required to enhance g(N2O5).
label: BODY

text: Interestingly, our observed g(N2O5) values are consistent
label: BODY

text: with that predicted by the Bertram and Thornton [2009]
label: BODY

text: parameterization regardless of the AS phase state. Labora-
label: BODY

text: tory measurements of g(N2O5) are <0.005 on crystalline AS
label: BODY

text: [Mozurkewich and Calvert, 1988], similar to the median of
label: BODY

text: 0.003 observed in Boulder. If AS crystallization was
label: BODY

text: inhibited by the available POM [Parsons et al., 2004] and
label: BODY

text: we treat POM as hygroscopic (i.e. malonic acid like),
label: BODY

text: Figure 1.
label: BODY

text: (a) Observed dependence of g(N2O5) on the
label: BODY

text: mass ratio of POM to SO4
label: BODY

text: 2 for measurements made in
label: BODY

text: Seattle (black) and Boulder (gray). (b) Calculated depen-
label: BODY

text: dence of the molar ratio of H2O(l) to NO3
label: BODY

text:  on the mass ratio
label: BODY

text: of POM to SO4
label: BODY

text: 2 for measurements made in Seattle,
label: BODY

text: assuming that POM does (circles) and does not (squares)
label: BODY

text: contribute to H2O(l) uptake. Data points are equal
label: BODY

text: population binned medians, where the bar corresponds to
label: BODY

text: the interquartile range of the calculations. The shaded
label: BODY

text: region (in panel b) represents values of [H2O(l)]/[NO3
label: BODY

text: where laboratory measurements predict suppression in
label: BODY

text: g(N2O5) due to the NO3
label: BODY

text:  effect.
label: BODY

text: 1Auxiliary materials are available in the HTML. doi:10.1029/
label: BODY

text: BERTRAM ET AL.: DIRECT OBSERVATIONS OF N2O5 REACTIVITY
label: BODY

text: 2 of 5
label: BODY

text: calculations made using the Bertram and Thornton [2009]
label: BODY

text: parameterization show that at the low RH sampled,
label: BODY

text: ] is low enough to significantly suppress
label: BODY

text: g(N2O5) to <0.005 across the entire range of POM/SO4
label: BODY

text: observed in Boulder. Co-located measurements of g(N2O5)
label: BODY

text: and particle phase state [Martin et al., 2008] will clearly
label: BODY

text: allow such distinctions to be made in the future.
label: BODY

text: [11] The behavior of g(N2O5) observed in Seattle, at
label: BODY

text: higher RH, more clearly illustrates the importance of
label: BODY

text: understanding POM in order to assess the factors control-
label: BODY

text: ling g(N2O5). The dependence of g(N2O5) on POM/SO4
label: BODY

text: was observed during a stagnation episode in which most of
label: BODY

text: the POM mass growth was likely due to SOA formation as
label: BODY

text: indicated by the fraction of POM that is measured to be
label: BODY

text: highly oxidized (see Figure S4). In light of the above
label: BODY

text: expectations, the decreasing g(N2O5) with increasing
label: BODY

text: POM/SO4
label: BODY

text: 2 can be hypothesized to be a result of: i) a
label: BODY

text: relative decrease in the particulate water mass fraction,
label: BODY

text: following increased partitioning of organics that are less
label: BODY

text: hygroscopic than AS (i.e. DH2O(l)/DPOM  0), leading to
label: BODY

text: both an increased nitrate effect [Wahner et al., 1998] and a
label: BODY

text: possible H2O(l) limitation [Thornton et al., 2003], and/or
label: BODY

text: ii) an increasing role of organic coatings that limit either
label: BODY

text: N2O5 surface accommodation or N2O5 accessibility to
label: BODY

text: H2O(l).
label: BODY

text: [12] To examine these suppositions, we first calculate
label: BODY

text: [H2O(l)] and [H2O(l)]/[NO3
label: BODY

text: ] using AIM for the two
label: BODY

text: extremes of POM hygroscopicity: i) POM does not con-
label: BODY

text: tribute to H2O(l) uptake, and ii) POM is highly hygroscopic,
label: BODY

text: contributing significantly to H2O(l) (POM treated as
label: BODY

text: malonic acid) (Figure 1b). In both cases [H2O(l)] is suffi-
label: BODY

text: ciently high (>20M), so as not to suppress g(N2O5) directly.
label: BODY

text: The molar ratio of H2O(l) to NO3
label: BODY

text:  remains nearly constant
label: BODY

text: when POM is allowed to contribute to H2O(l), but decreases
label: BODY

text: with increasing POM/SO4
label: BODY

text: 2 when POM is prohibited from
label: BODY

text: contributing to H2O(l). To determine whether the calculated
label: BODY

text: changes in [H2O(l)]/[NO3
label: BODY

text: ] are sufficient for describing the
label: BODY

text: observed changes in g(N2O5), we use the parameterization
label: BODY

text: for g(N2O5) described by Bertram and Thornton [2009].
label: BODY

text: [13] Figure 2 depicts the parameterization-observation
label: BODY

text: comparison for both cases as a function of the molar ratio
label: BODY

text: of H2O(l) to NO3
label: BODY

text: . The strong parameterization-observation
label: BODY

text: agreement, shown in panel A, lends support to the conclu-
label: BODY

text: sion that POM sampled in Seattle did not contribute
label: BODY

text: significantly to H2O(l). Such a notion would be generally
label: BODY

text: consistent with the findings of Mochida et al. [2008] and
label: BODY

text: Quinn et al. [2005], where ambient observations revealed
label: BODY

text: decreases in RH-dependent particle growth factors or scat-
label: BODY

text: tering efficiency in the presence of large organic mass
label: BODY

text: fractions. Based on our observations alone, we cannot rule
label: BODY

text: out the possibility that organic coatings may act to offset the
label: BODY

text: effects of hygroscopic organics (Figure 2b). Nonetheless, it
label: BODY

text: is clear that the presence and chemical properties of POM
label: BODY

text: play a decisive role in setting g(N2O5) in the troposphere.
label: BODY

text: Further measurements of g(N2O5) downwind of source
label: BODY

text: regions, where POM is likely more oxidized [Zhang et
label: BODY

text: al., 2007], and more hygroscopic [Kondo et al., 2007], and/
label: BODY

text: or alongside co-located observations of particle hygroscopic
label: BODY

text: growth will be strong tests of this hypothesis and the
label: BODY

text: applicability of these first results to regional and global
label: BODY

text: models.
label: BODY

text: Implications for NOx Processing Rates
label: BODY

text: [14] Quantifying the absolute magnitude of g(N2O5) and
label: BODY

text: ultimately the loss rate of N2O5 to particles is necessary for
label: BODY

text: reliable model representations of NOx, OH, O3, and particle
label: BODY

text: abundances and the couplings between them. The sensitiv-
label: BODY

text: ity of the NOx budget to g(N2O5) is a strong function of the
label: BODY

text: NO3 and N2O5 production rates, Sa, temperature, and NO3
label: BODY

text: reactivity. To assess the importance of g(N2O5) we examine
label: BODY

text: the fraction of NOx present at sunset, [NOx]sunset, that is lost
label: BODY

text: at night as a function of g(N2O5).
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: ratio of H2O(l) to NO3

label: BODY

text: uptake. Data points are separated into equal population bins, where the bar and whiskers correspond to the median to mean
label: BODY

text: range and the interquartile range of the observations, respectively. The parameterized g(N2O5), derived from the observed
label: BODY

text: particle chemical composition and RH, is shown with black solid lines and the shaded region represents the propagated
label: BODY

text: uncertainty in its determination. The dashed black line depicts g(N2O5) as parameterized for regions where direct
label: BODY

text: measurements of g(N2O5) were not available.
label: BODY

text: BERTRAM ET AL.: DIRECT OBSERVATIONS OF N2O5 REACTIVITY
label: BODY

text: 3 of 5
label: BODY

text: The dependence of Flost on g(N2O5) and NO3 reactivity, as
label: BODY

text: calculated using a time-dependent chemical box model (see
label: BODY

text: SI) for characteristic summer and winter conditions, is
label: BODY

text: shown in Figure 3. We chose conditions (e.g., temperature
label: BODY

text: and NO3 reactivity) in order to bracket the range of possible
label: BODY

text: sensitivities to g(N2O5). In our summer calculations, Flost is
label: BODY

text: primarily limited by the NO3 production rate and nearly
label: BODY

text: independent of g(N2O5) due to assuming high loadings of
label: BODY

text: biogenic volatile organic compounds (BVOC), which
label: BODY

text: increase NO3 reactivity, and warmer temperatures, which
label: BODY

text: shift the N2O5-NO3 equilibrium in favor of NO3. The result
label: BODY

text: is that at high NO3 reactivity the nocturnal loss of NOx is
label: BODY

text: independent of g(N2O5). During winter, BVOC emissions
label: BODY

text: are significantly smaller, and lower temperatures shift the
label: BODY

text: N2O5-NO3 equilibrium in favor of N2O5. As a result, Flost is
label: BODY

text: far more sensitive to g(N2O5) during winter than in summer.
label: BODY

text: These calculations illustrate the acute sensitivity of the NOx
label: BODY

text: budget to changes in g(N2O5) between 1  104 and 0.1
label: BODY

text: and imply that the NOx lifetime is strongly dependent on
label: BODY

text: NO3 reactivity at low g(N2O5).
label: BODY

text: [15] In addition to accurate predictions of the total
label: BODY

text: nocturnal NOx loss, models must also correctly attribute
label: BODY

text: that loss between the N2O5 and NO3 channels to achieve a
label: BODY

text: realistic sensitivity of the NOx budget to changes in VOC,
label: BODY

text: temperature, and particle loadings. Our modeling shows this
label: BODY

text: branching is sensitive to g(N2O5) for the majority of likely
label: BODY

text: conditions. The reaction products for the two channels have
label: BODY

text: different effects on oxidant concentrations and particle mass
label: BODY

text: loadings: the products of NO3 homogeneous reactions can
label: BODY

text: lead to the formation of secondary organic aerosol [Ng et
label: BODY

text: al., 2008] and the heterogeneous reaction of N2O5 can lead
label: BODY

text: to halogen activation [Finlayson-Pitts et al., 1989] or
label: BODY

text: increased particulate nitrate mass [Riemer et al., 2003].
label: BODY

text: [16] When compared to predictions of g(N2O5) made
label: BODY

text: using two currently implemented large-scale model param-
label: BODY

text: eterizations [Davis et al., 2008; Evans and Jacob, 2005],
label: BODY

text: our directly observed reactivity values are both more
label: BODY

text: variable and as much as a factor of ten lower, consistent
label: BODY

text: with reactivity values inferred from aircraft observations of
label: BODY

text: NO3 and N2O5 [Brown et al., 2009]. If our observations
label: BODY

text: described herein are representative of other urban/suburban
label: BODY

text: locations, then incorporating the observed g(N2O5) into
label: BODY

text: current models would likely lead to increases in predicted
label: BODY

text: O3 and OH, and an increased sensitivity of NOx loss to both
label: BODY

text: NO3 reactivity and particle loadings.
label: BODY

text: Conclusions
label: BODY

text: [17] We present an analysis of the first direct measure-
label: BODY

text: ments of g(N2O5) on ambient aerosol particles. At the limit
label: BODY

text: of low POM, our observations confirm RH as a primary
label: BODY

text: control and particulate nitrate as a secondary control in
label: BODY

text: regulating g(N2O5). Observations at high RH illustrate a
label: BODY

text: strong dependence of g(N2O5) on particle POM/SO4
label: BODY

text: 2. Our
label: BODY

text: recent parameterization [Bertram and Thornton, 2009] can
label: BODY

text: adequately capture the trend and variability in the observed
label: BODY

text: g(N2O5) if we make the assumption that the increasing
label: BODY

text: POM mass fractions do not contribute significantly to
label: BODY

text: additional particulate water uptake at the same RH. In such
label: BODY

text: a case, the nitrate effect is sufficient to explain our results. If
label: BODY

text: POM does contribute to H2O(l) uptake, then our results
label: BODY

text: suggest an additional means of suppressing g(N2O5) that is
label: BODY

text: correlated with oxidized POM such as organic coatings.
label: BODY

text: Regardless, these results clearly indicate that regional and
label: BODY

text: global modeling efforts need to consider the effects of
label: BODY

text: particulate organic loadings and hygroscopicity in parame-
label: BODY

text: terizing the rate of nocturnal NOx loss via N2O5 reactions
label: BODY

text: on particles.
label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY
